Ella desde hace mas de 4 años se dedica al cultivo de aguacate, ella dice “mi esposo me dejo un negocio muy pesado en mantenimiento pero gracias a este puedo sacar adelante a mi hijo que estudia ya que yo no puede estudiar por falta de recursos me tengo que dedicar a la tierra que me dejo mi difunto esposo que gracias a los 3 créditos que me han hecho lo he podido sacar adelante ya que lo descuide un poco cuando mi marido falleció pero ahorita están en buenas condiciones”. Dice que está pidiendo el crédito para comprar abono orgánico, fertilizantes e insecticidas para que no le peguen las heladas fuertes y puedan aguantar los granizos que caen en la temporada de invierno. Dice que ahorita tiene aproximadamente 200 árboles y espera seguir sembrando más ya que su terreno  esta grande casi son dos hectáreas y quiere cubrirlo de este tipo de fruto, plática que cuando es temporada de cosechar va a la central de abastos a venderlos por kilos ya que le sale mejor venderlos así y dice que las ultimas cosechas le han ido bien en la corta porque a sacado bastante. Su mayor anhelo es que su hijo el menor tenga una carrera para que no sufra trabajar en el campo y que sus hijas vuelvan a estudiar porque no le gusta que estén tan lejos de ella, también quiere seguir comprando matas de aguacate para seguir cultivando y dejarle a sus hijos un negocio bueno. Las demás integrantes del grupo se llaman Eulalia, María del Carmen, María Luisa, María, Alicia, María Angélica, Lorena, Rosario y Sandra ellas invertirán en la compra de fertilizantes, abonos orgánicos para el cultivo de aguacate, para la compra de alimento y vacunas para cerdos, compra de fertilizantes y abonos para cultivo de jitomate y para la compra de artículos para surtir tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Ricarda is a hardworking woman.  She’s 44-year-old and a widow.  She’s a member of the “Los Encinos Ganadería” group.  She says they gave it this name because where they live oak trees are common and the ‘ganadería’ part is because most of the members work raising pigs, cattle and sheep.  She says that at her husband’s death, she’s had to take on her children’s care all by herself.  Back then, the three of them were students but now two of her daughters work in Mexico City as domestic employees and they help her support her son who is attending high-school with much sacrifice.

She’s been growing avocadoes for more than four years.  She says: “My husband left me a business that requires much hard work to care for but thanks to it I’m able to move my son, who is studying, forward since I was unable to study due to the lack of resources.  I have to devote myself to the land my late husband left me and thanks to the three loans I’ve gotten I’ve been able to move it forward even though I did neglect it somewhat when my husband died but now it’s in good condition.”  She says she’s asking for this loan to buy organic manure, fertilizer and insecticide to protect against the chilling frosts and hail storms that are common in winter.  

She says that she now has about 200 trees and hopes to continue planting more since her field is large; it’s almost two hectares and she wants to cover it entirely with this type of fruit.  She relates that when it’s harvest time she heads to the wholesale food market to sell them by the kilo since it’s more profitable to sell them that way.  She says the last few harvests have been good since her yields were quite large.  

Her greatest hope is that her youngest son will have a career so he will not have to suffer working in the fields and that her daughters can restart their schooling because she does not like their being so far from her.  She also wants to continue to buy avocado plants to continue growing them and leave a good business for her children.

The other group members’ names are Eulalia, María del Carmen, María Luisa, María, Alicia, María Angélica, Lorena, Rosario and Sandra and they will use their loans to buy fertilizer, organic manure for avocado farming, will buy feed and vaccines for pigs, fertilizer and manure for tomato crops and will buy merchandise to stock a grocery store.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Invierno Group

texts.es: Elizabeth tiene 30 años y comenta “justamente hoy que recibo mi nuevo crédito es día de mi cumpleaños y me siento alegre y feliz porque estoy empezando un nuevo año de vida con mucho ánimo porque gracias a lo que me van a prestar voy a surtir mi negocio”.  Ella es parte del grupo Invierno y dice que le pusieron ese nombre al grupo porque cuando tiene más actividad económica su pueblo es en la temporada de invierno ya que donde vive se encuentra el santuario de la mariposa monarca donde año con año arriban las grandiosas mariposas para dar un espectáculo sin igual y donde miles de turistas de todo el mundo van a admirar las bellezas de la naturaleza. Dice que a ella le llena de orgullo ser parte de un pueblo como este ya que se conoce gente de todo el mundo y pueden ver los turistas las artesanías que hacen los pueblos indígenas de Michoacán. Dice que casi todo el año ella se dedica a bordar servilletas, manteles, almohadones con lo representativo de su pueblo, es decir, las mariposas monarca y que las vende en poblaciones aledañas a su comunidad y que ahorita está pidiendo un crédito para la compra de material porque a partir del 20 de noviembre de cada año se abre el santuario y empiezan a llegar los turistas y quiere surtir para vender afuera del santuario  como playeras, recuerdos como llaveros, lapiceros, cuadros de madera con fotografías de las mariposas ya que tiene su puesto desde hace mas de 14 años. Ella tiene tres hijos y está casada con el señor Daniel quien trabaja como jornalero. Comenta que cuando termina la temporada de mariposa que es a mediados de marzo es cuando empieza a vender en su tiendita de abarrotes que tiene en su casa. Su meta en su negocio es tratar de conseguir un puesto estable en el santuario para que cada año pueda vender sus artesanías y no tenga que pagar tanto impuesto que le cobran por poner su puesto de artesanías y recuerdos de la mariposa. Las otras cuatro integrantes del grupo se llaman Teresa, Imelda, Rosa y Adela ellas invertirán sus créditos que les otorgaran en la compra de insumos para elaborar pan de rancho, para la compra de artículos para surtir tienda de abarrotes, para la compra de insumos para elaborar antojitos mexicanos.
texts.en:
Elizabeth, 30, comments: “The very day when I’m getting my new loan is my birthday and I feel happy and joyful because I’m starting a new year of life very encouraged because thanks to what I’m going to be lent I will be able to stock my business.”  She’s part of the “Invierno” (Winter) group and she says they named it thus because winter is when her town has the most economic activity because they live in a zone where the monarch butterfly sanctuary is located and every year the magnificent butterflies arrive to produce an unequalled spectacle that draws thousands of tourists from all over the world that come to admire nature’s beauty.  

She says that it fills her with pride to be part of a town like this one that people from all over the world know about and tourists from all over the world can admire the crafts the indigenous peoples of Michoacán make.  She says that she spends most of the year embroidering napkins, tablecloths and cushions with scenes representative of her town, that is, monarch butterflies that she sells in towns adjacent to her community.  She’s now asking for a loan to buy supplies because starting on November 20th each year the sanctuary opens and tourists start arriving and she wants to be stocked up to sell outside the sanctuary.  She sells t-shirts, keepsakes like key rings, pencils, wood picture frames with photos of the butterflies, etc.  She’s had her stand for more than 14 years.

She has three children and is married to Daniel who works as a day laborer.  She comments that when the butterfly season ends in mid-March she works selling in her little, home-based grocery store.  Her business goal is to try to get a stationary stand in the sanctuary so that she can sell her crafts each year and not have to pay the high taxes she’s charged to set up her crafts and butterfly keepsake stand.

The other four members of the group are Teresa, Imelda, Rosa and Adela.  They will invest the loans they are granted into buying ingredients to make rustic bread, to buy grocery store stock merchandise and to buy ingredients to make Mexican fast-food snacks.

loans.use: to buy crafts and embroidery supplies.

loans.name: Aves De Paraíso Group

texts.es: Don Florencio tiene 48 años de edad y es originario de una comunidad llamada Valle Verde un lugar lleno de vegetación y donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedica al comercio, platica don Florencio que tiene menos de un año trabajando con VisionFund y que le ha ido muy bien en su negocio a través de los créditos que le han hecho y eso lo tiene muy contento porque puede sacar adelante a su familia. El pertenece a un grupo llamado “Aves de Paraíso” le pusieron ese nombre al grupo por que donde se reunían había una mata con ese tipo de flores que no son muy comunes en la región y aparte porque son muy bonitas. El se dedica a elaborar nieves como son de fresa, coco, vainilla, limón, chocolate, mamey, queso, chongos  y de muchas más pero esas son las que le piden más sus clientes que más que nada son niños y jóvenes ya que vende afuera de la primaria y secundaria de su comunidad. Dice que está pidiendo un crédito para la compra de insumos para elaborar las nieves como son leche, colorantes, frutas, hielo, sal de grano, azúcar, conos, servilletas dice que desde muy temprana hora se levanta hacer sus nieves porque a la hora de la salidas de los muchachos la nieve debe estar lista dice que primero hace el preparado pero en general si son frutas se muelen, si es de leche se prepara con vainilla. El chiste es el helado, dice que se pone en un bote grande con hielos adentro y sal de grano para que no se derritan pronto, después se pone dentro del bote un bote de aluminio o de cualquier fierro y se empieza a girar el bote interno al mismo tiempo se dan batidas ocasionales con un globo de metal hasta que se congela el helado dice que a diario hace esto para llevar hasta las escuelas sus ricos y deliciosos helados, platica que empezó esta actividad por la falta de un trabajo estable y un amigo de él le dijo como hacer los helados y pensó en dedicarse por completo a este trabajo que tiene el. El comenta “me gusta lo que hago porque ya tengo mis clientes además soy jefe de mi negocio y tengo tiempo de mantener a mi familia”. El tiene cuatro hijos los cuales estudian en la secundaria y primaria y por eso trabaja muy duro para darles lo mejor y nos les falte nada para su educación. La meta de don Florencio es comprar un triciclo mas nuevo ya que el que tiene esta deteriorado y a cada rato se le ponchan las llantas el quisiera cambiarlo por uno nuevo y pagarlo en pagos chiquitos. Las otras nueve integrantes del grupo se llaman Isela, María Remedios, Cirenia, Socorro, Yaquelin, Marcela, María Llasmin, Sandra y Maribel ellas  invertirán en sus negocios como lo son para la compra de maíz para hacer tortillas a mano, para la compra de artículos para surtir tienda de abarrotes, para la compra de madera para hacer cajas para vender a los fruteros, para  la compra de materiales para construcción para vender como son arena, tabique y cemento, para la compra de frutas y legumbre de temporada para vender, para la compra de alimento para pollos y para la compra de pollitos para crianza y venderlos y para la compra de dulces y venderlos afuera de una escuela.
texts.en: Florencio is 48 years old and a native of a community called Valle Verde that is full of lush vegetation and where the majority of the inhabitants make a living in commerce. Florencio has worked with VisionFund for less than a year and the loans have helped his business go very well, so he is very content because he can make headway for his family. He belongs to a group called "Aves de Paraíso" ("Birds of Paradise"), which gave itself this name because their meeting place has a thicket of flowers of the same name that aren't very common in the region and are very beautiful. Florencio makes a living making ice creams and sorbets, with flavors like strawberry, coconut, vanilla, lemon, chocolate, apple, cheese, and many others, but these are the ones most requested by his customers, who are mostly children and youths since he sells outside of a elementary and high school in his community. He says that he is requesting the loan to purchase supplies to make his sorbets, such as milk, food dyes, fruits, ice, rock salt, sugar, cones and napkins. He says that he gets up very early to make his sorbets because they need to be ready by the time the children leave school. First he grounds the fruit or adds vanilla to the milk. The trick is with the ice cream. He says that he puts ice and rock salt inside a big pot so it doesn't melt too quickly, and then he puts another metal canister inside with the ingredients and slowly churns it as the ice cream freezes. He says he does this every day so he can take his delicious and rich ice creams to the school. He says that he started this job because he could not find stable work and a friend told him how to make ice cream, so he decided to take up the work. He says, "I enjoy what I do because I already have my customers, and I'm my own boss and have time to be with my family." He has four children who are in elementary and high school, and for this reason he works very hard to provide them with the best and so they don't lack anything in regards to their education. His goal is to purchase a newer moto-tricycle, because the one he has is deteriorating and every time he punctures a tire he has to change it for a new one and pay for it in small payments. The other nine members are Isela, María Remedios, Cirenia, Socorro, Yaquelin, Marcela, María Llasmin, Sandra and Maribel. They invested their loans in ingredients to make tortillas; in the purchase of items for their grocery store; construction materials that they sell; sweets and different savories that they sell; sweets and fritters to sell; seasonal fruit and vegetables; chicken to raise and later sell, etc.

loans.use: purchase ingredients to make sorbets.

loans.name: Mateo Yaxón Chumil

texts.es:
Mateo  es un hombre agricultor de 70  años de edad, el esta casado y vive en Sololá.  El tiene 7 hijos de ellos seis varones de ellos cuatro  están casados y una mujer que también esta casada y trabajan independientemente, y dos varones que aun viven con el y lo apoyan en el campo.
El se dedica a la agricultura cultivando papa, cebolla, zanahoria y ejote, en unas parcelas que tiene  a pocos kilómetros de su vivienda, esto lo aprendió de su padre ya que no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar en alguna escuela. 
Antes de realizar su propio cultivo el trabajo junto a su hermana donde perfecciono y obtuvo mas experiencia en este trabajo .
El ahora cuenta con 25 años de realizar su propio cultivo viendo que obtiene ganancias aceptables, de este modo el solicita un préstamo de   Q 4,000.00 para que pueda comprar semillas  de papa y su fertilizante para luego cultivarlo y cosecharlo mejorando sus ingresos y condiciones de vida de su familia.
Con sus ganancias el sueña la compra de una parcela mas  y poder expandir su cultivo obteniendo mejores ganancias en un futuro.
texts.en:
Mateo, 70, is a farmer. He is married and lives in Sololá. He has seven children. Four of his six sons are married, and his daughter is married too. They work independently.Two of his sons still live with him and help him in the fields. He works in agriculture, growing potatoes, onions, carrots, and green beans on some parcels of land that he has a few kilometers from his home. He learned this trade from his father, because he did not have the chance to study in school.

Before he had his own crop, he worked with his sister, where he perfected and gained more experience in his work. Now he has had his own crop for 25 years, and he has had acceptable earnings. This is why is applying for a loan of Q 4,000.00 so that he can buy potato seeds and fertilizer. He will plant it and harvest it and improve his earnings and his family's quality of life. With his earnings, he dreams of buying another parcel and being able to expand his crop and earn more money in the future.

loans.use: to buy potato seeds and fertilizer for his crop

loans.name: Abriendo Surcos Group

texts.es:
María es una mujer de 62 años, creció en una familia de escasos recursos, por lo que alcanzó a sustentarse solamente los estudios primarios. Se separó de su pareja hace varios años lo cual fue algo muy doloroso en su vida y representó un obstáculo en el emprendimiento de un negocio. María educa a su  nieto que tiene 13 años debido a algunos problemas que la madre del chico tiene con su horario de trabajo. Viven en Quinindé un cantón de la Provincia de Esmeraldas que provee a varias ciudades del Ecuador productos como banano, cacao, café, palma africana y productos forestales y además el comercio es el trabajo diario de la mayoría de sus habitantes para poder salir adelante y más aún cuando han incrementado las vías para llegar a este cantón lo que ha permitido un gran movimiento comercial en especial los fines de semana en donde salen comerciantes de todo tipo a ofertar sus productos en la feria a sus potenciales clientes que la mayoría de veces suelen ser campesinos. El turismo también es un aporte muy importante para este cantón pues su ecosistema natural tiene mucha variedad de lugares para ser visitados cascadas, ríos de agua dulce,  bosques, que tienen flores y animales que adornan esta ciudad. Cada familia de este lugar se esfuerza y busca todas las alternativas para mejorar su calidad de vida, por lo que se puede hablar de un cantón emprendedor.
María estableció su taller de costura desde hace algunos años, aprendió con la experiencia y poco a poco fue mejorando, ahora es toda una experta e invierte entre 8 y 10 horas en la elaboración de ropa para toda ocasión, según la demanda de sus clientes. Ella requiere un préstamo para comprar telas distintas y de esta forma poder ofrecer otra variedad de estilos al momento de confeccionar la ropa. María espera que esto incremente sus ingresos pues ella sueña tener un taller grande confeccionando ropa para venderla por todo el país y con esto lograr pagar los estudios de su nieto hasta que se convierta en todo un profesional. María se ha unido con amigos que también tienen necesidad de engrandecer sus negocios como es el caso de Jofre quien se dedica a la crianza y venta de cerdos, como lo hace Julio quien aparte de cerdos, vende pescado, y a esta actividad también se dedica Cruz quien comercializa cerdos y pollos María quien cria pollos para su posterior venta, Teresa, María y Verónica quienes venden ropa por catálogo, al igual que Sonia quien a pesar de una discapacidad física también vende bisutería de forma ambulante, Patricio y Angela cada uno con su tienda de víveres.
texts.en: María is 62 years old. She grew up in a poor family, so she only managed to get through elementary school. She separated from her husband a number of years ago, which was something very painful in her life and represented an obstacle in pursuing her business. María raises her 13-year-old grandson because of some problems the boy's mother has with her work schedule. They live in Quinindé, a hamlet in the province of Esmeraldas that provides a number of cities in Ecuador with bananas, cacao, coffee, palm and forest products, and the majority of the inhabitants make a living in commerce. That has become even more the case since the roads into town were expanded, allowing a lot of commercial movement, especially on the weekends when merchants of all kinds go out to offer their products at the area flea markets. Tourism is another important industry because the natural ecosystem offers a wide variety of places to see waterfalls, rivers and forests full of flowers and animals. Every family works hard and looks for new ways to improve their quality of life, so one could call this an enterprising place. María started her seamstress shop a number of years ago. She learned from experience and little by little improved her craft, and now she is an expert and spends between eight and 10 hours a day making clothing for all occasions, according to the demands of her customers. She is requesting the loan to purchase distinct fabrics and in this way she can offer a wider variety of styles. She hopes this will increase her income, since her goal is to have a big seamstress shop making clothes to sell all over the country, and with that she will be able to pay for her grandson's education until he becomes a professional. María has joined with friends who also need to expand their businesses, as is the case with Jofre, who makes a living raising and selling pigs. Juilo raises pigs and sells fish, while Cruz sells pigs and chickens. Another María raises and sells chickens. Teresa, Verónica and another María sell clothing via catalog, same as Sonia, who despite a physical disability also sells jewelry. Patricio and Angela have grocery stores.

loans.use: to purchase fabric to make seasonal clothing.

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Dulamsuren is 52 years old and lives with her son in their four-room house in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.  She has been working as an education manager for 6 years in a special training school for children with dysphasia.  Her eldest son works in Korea as a contract worker.  Her younger one is a journalist, working in television as a sports commentator.  Dulamsuren rents two of her rooms to students from the countryside.  

In the future, once she is retired, Dulamsuren wants to establish her own school for children with dysphasia.  So she initially planned and built her house to meet standards in order to bring this dream to life.  Due to the lack of money, she is approaching her goal little by little and doing certain things each year.  This time Dulamsuren is planning to solve the heating problem of the house.  Her loan will be used to insulate the house walls on both sides and to install an electric heating system that emits less carbon dioxide into atmosphere.  By doing this she can reduce heating expenses and, at the same time, save the environment.

loans.use: to warm her home by installing a heating system and insulating the walls.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy basic supplies such as flashlights, locks and rechargeable lamps.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes, shoes and handbags that she will sell in her hair salon.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 59 years old and widowed with 13 children.  She is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines, and has been doing so for 18 years.  She has borrowed from NWTF 17 times in the past to sustain this business.  

Editha requested a loan of 12,000 (PHP) to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.  In the future, Editha would like to save enough money to improve the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

loans.name: Elena

texts.ru: Елена торгует на рынке женкской одеждой: брюки, штаны, кофты, куртки, пр. Торговая точка Елены расположена в удачном для торговли месте. Елена - клиент ответственный, порядочный и пунктуальный, по кредитам платит всегда без опозданий. В этот раз кредит понадобился Елене для оптовой закупки женской одежды.
texts.en: Elena works as a market vendor and sells women's clothing such as slacks, pants,  sweaters, jackets, etc.  Her retail outlet is ideally located, which is good for business.  Elena is a responsible, honest and punctual client who has always repaid her loans on time.  She currently needs a loan to buy women's clothing in bulk quantities.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing.

loans.name: Remelyn

texts.en:
Remelyn is 28 years old and married with three children. Two of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Remelyn has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines. Remelyn requested a 20000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy spare parts for her tricycle transport.

Remelyn has been in this business for three years. In the future, Remelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle transport.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fabrics, linens, blankets, and incense.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita, age 49, is married with six children. She is from Taguitic, Kapatagan, Lanao Del Norte. To make a living, Merlita raises hogs for sale. Merlita has been engaged in her business for six years and earns 6,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) a month. Merlita joined GDMPC in 2008. 

Merlita is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase feeding supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeding supplies.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana started her business a year ago with her own working capital. Now she is applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business by buying beer, oil, coffee, sugar and petrol to sell.

She has three children, and her husband is very helpful in doing business because he is also a businessman.
 
Her business place is very crowded and many people come to buy. She is making a good income. She lives in her simple house made of palm branches and zinc for the roof. She wants to make her kiosk into a big store in the future. None of her children are in the school; they are all underage.

loans.use: to buy beer, oil, coffee, sugar and petrol.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 30-year-old single mother living in Masindi, Uganda. Sarah sells vegetables, and with the proceeds she has been able to provide basics for her child. She started her business 12 years ago. Like most good mothers she hopes of her child being educated to attain a degree.

Sarah faces a challenge of the perishable nature of her goods, and her dream is to buy a refrigerator and diversify her business to include general merchandise. Sarah is requesting a loan to buy general merchandise, such as soap and salt, to sell.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise, such as soap and salt, to sell.

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is 43 years old. She lives in the Chkhorotsku District with her husband and two children. 

Nino had requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected every time because of her low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from their agricultural business. In particular, they have 0.5 hectare of land, where 150 nut trees and 5 persimmon trees are grown. It brings hardly enough for food to a four-member family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Nino has requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. 

The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits, with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” due to their low incomes. 

With the received credit, Nino will begin trading with clothing. Nino plans to purchase clothing from wholesalers and resell it among her villagers. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will increase the income and will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase clothing from wholesalers to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a chaff cutter

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita, 48, is married with 4 children, living in Poblacion, Aurora. In order to add income in the family, she manages a retail business which started 3 years ago. She usually gets 3,000 PHP per month. With the help of GDMPC microcredit, Teresita is able to procure more bottles of drinks to sell because of the amount of 7,000 PHP rendered to her. She joined GDMPC in 2011. Someday, she’s hoping for much greater revenue for business expansion.

loans.use: to procure more bottles of drinks to sell

loans.name: Claire Leonce Martine

texts.fr: Claire Leonce Martine est une jeune Camerounaise âgée de 26 ans, fiancée et mère de 04 enfants allant tous à l'école. elle mène une activité de couture à domicile depuis 02 ans déjà. elle coud sur commande et ensuite les livres en gros auprès des détaillants. elle travaille seule et ne dispose que d'une seule machine. elle voudrait avec ce crédit acheter 02 machines à coudre et des rouleaux de tissus car elle a pour ambition non seulement de s'installer en ville, mais aussi de se lancer dans la formation en couture.
texts.en: Claire Leonce Martine is a young Cameroonian woman.  At 26 years old, she is engaged as well as the mother of four children, all of whom attend school.  For two years now, she has been doing business sewing at home.  She sews to-order and then delivers in bulk to retailers.  She works alone and has only one machine at her disposal. With this loan she would like to buy two sewing machines and rolls of fabric, since she aspires not only to settle in the city, but also to begin training for her sewing.

loans.use: to purchase two sewing machines and rolls of fabric.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en: Faridah is aged 28, a single mother of two children living in Masindi, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after them solely rests on her since her former husband got another family and her desire is to educate her children up to the University. She has a food production business and works 10 hours a day. She started the business 13 years ago after dropping out of school due to lack of school fees. She is a market vendor and is challenged by high transport costs and the rainy season while her business desire is to rent business premises and diversify her business to include a retail shop. Faridah is requesting a loan to buy food items such as beans and maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy food items such as beans and maize to sell.

loans.name: Oleg

texts.ru:
Олег торгует на рынке «1000» мелочей» велосипедами и запчастями к ним, а также продает тачки, санки, лопаты и др. В этот раз кредит понадобился Олегу для закупки велозапчастей: шины, спицы, втулки, сиденья и т.д. Олег  отзывчив, дисциплинирован, платит без опозданий; торговое место Олега рассположено  в хорошем месте.
Олег имеет постоянных провереннных надежных поставщиков, привозит качественный товар, что служит хорошей возможностью иметь постоянных покупателей.
texts.en:
Oleg sells bicycles and spare parts at the market "1000 Trifles". He also sells wheelbarrows, sleds, shovels and other items. This time, Oleg needs a loan to stock up on spare parts for bicycles: spokes, tires, wheel hubs, saddles etc.

Oleg is responsible and disciplined, and pays back his loans on time. His retail spot is located advantageously. He has a number of established, tested, and reliable suppliers, and stocks quality merchandise, which serves well to attract regular customers.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for bicycles - tires, spokes, saddles, etc.

loans.name: Houenoussou 3 Group

texts.fr: Le groupement HOUENOUSSOU 3 est composé de vingt huit personnes qui vivent dans la même zone. C'est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Faissathou est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Faissathou est âgée de 64 ans et vit au Bénin. Faissathou est mariée à un certain Christian. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés, dont deux restent à leur charge. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Faissathou n’a pas fréquenté. Faissathou vend depuis une trentaine d'année, des bijoux dans sa région. Faissathou s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu, Faissathou sollicite, ensemble avec son groupe, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
The Houenoussou 3 Group is made up of 28 people who live in the same area.  This is the first time that the group has asked for a loan via ALIDé, which they are doing in order to raise the levels of their businesses.  The representative of the group, named Faissathou, is pictured with his hand raised.  Faissouthou is 64 years old and lives in Bénin.  He is married to Christian.  The couple has five children, all in school, of whom two are still dependents.  The couple work togther to provide for the various household expenses.  Faissathou did not go to school.

For thirty years, Faissathou has been selling jewelry in his region.  He buys his stock at a market in Bénin.  In pursuit of customer satisfaction and to grow his turnover and profit, Faissathou is asking for his first loan through ALIDé along with his group.

loans.use: to purchase jewelry.

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
José, de 47 años, es un hombre esforzado y amable. Vive en su casa propia junto a su conviviente  Ameli, quien tiene un salón de belleza y le esta yendo muy bien. Crían juntos a sus hijos 3 hijos de 22, 15 y 4años. Esperan darles una buena educación.   
El trabajo de José consiste en la venta de repuestos de vehículos motorizados como bujías, cadenas, palieres,  entre otros. También se dedica a la reparación de estos vehículos. Arregla motores, palieres, sistemas eléctricos, etc. Este trabajo lo realiza en un local al interior de su propia vivienda. Se inició en esta actividad a la edad de 12 años ayudando en una mecánica a su tío, desde ahí descubrió cual seria la vocación para toda la vida. Lleva 35 años en esta actividad y en este tiempo cuenta con al ayuda su hijo, un ayudante y un practicante de un instituto. Comenta que su negocio es rentable porque la inversión lo realiza una sola vez, que es comprar herramientas necesarias para el arreglo de estos vehículos. Antes de dedicarse a esta actividad, decidió incursionar en el negocio de la compra y venta de árboles maderables. Pero como no conocía nada sobre este rubro lo estafaron y  perdió todo su capital. Entonces tomo la decisión de volver a reparar vehículos, que es lo mejor que sabe hacer  y también porque trabajaría en casa, permitiéndole estar a lado de su familia. Espera en el futuro  mejorar su local de atención, poner un  torno y una rectificadora. 
 Por tanto solicita 2,500 soles, para comprar repuestos  como bujías, cadenas, palieres,  etc. adquirirá estos productos al por mayor en la ciudad de Lima. De esta manera incrementara sus ganancias económicas.
texts.en:
José, age 47, is a determined and kind man. He lives in his own home with his common-law partner Ameli, who manages a beauty salon and has been doing very well. They have three children (ages 22, 15, and 4) and want to provide them a good education.

José’s work involves selling spare parts for motorized vehicles such as spark plugs, chains, bearings, and other items. He also performs vehicle repairs and is able to fix engines, bearings, electrical systems, and many other things. José performs his work in a shop located inside of his home. He started in this line of work at the age of 12 by helping out at his uncle’s repair shop. At that point, he knew that this would be the career he wanted to pursue. José has been doing this type of work for 35 years and now he has the help of his son, who works as his assistant and is also practicing the trade at an institute. He says that his business is profitable because he only had to make an initial investment – the purchase of the necessary tools for repairing vehicles. Prior to pursuing this profession full-time, José thought he would start a business of buying and selling timber. However, he did not know anything about this trade, so he ended up getting swindled and losing all of his capital. After that, he made the decision to return to his previous skillset of repairing vehicles since that is what he knows best. In addition, he would have the opportunity to work at home and be with his family. He hopes to improve his shop in the future by acquiring a lathe and a grinder.

José is requesting a loan of 2,500 PEN so that he can buy spare parts such as spark plugs, chains, bearings, and other items. He will buy these items wholesale in the city of Lima, which will help him increase his earnings.

loans.use: to buy spark plugs, chains, bearings, and other spare parts.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is from Lantungan, Aurora. She is 50 years old. She is married and has 2 kids. To make a living, she makes and sells snack food. She has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns about 3,000 PHP a month from this business. In 2011, she joined GDMPC. Alma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP. This loan will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice and other goods for her kiosk.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio, single, is 26 years old and lives in Solinog, Calamba. Rogelio is operating a general store, selling a variety of products to local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for two years and every month he earns PHP 3,000 from this work. 

He has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase new items such as candies, milo (brand of malted milk), shampoo, soaps etc. Recently, Rogelio joined GDMPC. Rogelio hopes to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo (brand of malted milk), shampoo and soaps.

loans.name: Tengiz

texts.en:
Tengiz is 39 years old. He lives in a small village of Tetritskaro District with his wife and two children. Tengiz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from the dairy business. In particular, they have two milk cows, whose milk is used in dairy products. Tengizi’s wife produces cheese and yogurt and sells it at a good price with milk. It is hardly enough income for food for a four-member family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence-poor category. 

Tengiz requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit Tengiz will purchase a minibus. After purchasing a minibus, Tengiz plans to go to the capital city with his minibus and sell milk, yogurt and cheese there. He will be able to transport more dairy products with the minibus and this will significantly increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a minibus so he can transport dairy products to the capital city.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana lives in Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. Aged 45, she is a widow and has three children. For the last seven years, she has made a living through raising corn for sale. She earns about 3,000 PHP a month. 

In 2009, Susana joined GDMPC. She is applying for a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue she earns as a result of this loan to continue improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Epripras

texts.en:
Epripras is a widow who has four children. She is 62 years old, and lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Epripras owns and operates a coco plantation, harvesting and selling coconuts to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years. She makes PHP 8,500 a month from her business. 

She has requested a loan of PHP 33,000 to pay for the cost of farm maintenance. Epripras joined GDMPC in 2010. Epripras wants to save the revenue generated from the business as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to pay for the cost of farm maintenance.

loans.name: Olivia's Group

texts.en:
Olivia's group is composed of two hardworking women. Olivia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Olivia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, in which she sells flour, sugar, soap, and cooking oil.

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like soda, sugar, Splash brand juice, and cooking oil for resale. This will help Olivia to generate greater profits and pay for her medical bills and her child. Olivia hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. She makes sure that she works hard to see that she educates her child.

Olivia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more commodities like soda, sugar, Splash juice, and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Prudence's Group

texts.en:
Prudence's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Prudence is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kamwenge in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Prudence has been working hard to manage her small business selling clothes. 

To help expand her business, Prudence has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to resell and will help Prudence to generate greater profits and pay for her medical bills and her children. Prudence hopes that, in the future, she will be able to educate her children up to the university level and also buy a plot of land. 

Prudence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Parsiano

texts.en:
Parsiano is 34 years old and lives in the town of Lyantonde in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children, with 3 of them currently in school. In the past 12 years, Parsiano has been working hard to manage his bar and restaurant, which sells variety of different drinks such as lemonade and beer . 

To help expand his business, Parsiano has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to obtain more stock of drinks such as lemonade for resale, and will help Parsiano to generate greater and increased profits to live a better life. Parsiano hopes that in the future he will be able to raise funds to make a bigger bar . 

Parsiano is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Parsiano who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to obtain more stock of drinks such as lemonade for resale

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en:
Herbert is 47 years old and lives in the town of Lyantonde in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 20 years, Herbert has been working hard to manage his farming, which trades in milk products like ghee, milk and skins. 

To help expand his business, Herbert has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to get more animals for the business and will help Herbert to generate greater profits, sell milk products and buy all the necessities for the family. Herbert hopes that in the future he will be able to have a bigger farm. 

Herbert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Herbert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to get more animals for the business

loans.name: Enock

texts.en:
Enock is 48 years old and lives in the town of Mbarara in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 6 years, Enock has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which trades in groceries. 

To help expand his business, Enock has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to procure more items for the store such us sugar, salt and bread to be sold and will help Enock to generate greater profits and increase on business sales. Enock hopes that in the future he will be able to become self-reliant. 

Enock is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Enock who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to procure more items for the store such us sugar, salt and bread to be sold

loans.name: Hadiya

texts.en:
Hadiya is 42 years old and lives in the town of Mbarara in the Mbarara region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Hadiya has been working hard to manage her grocery store, which sells sugar, rice, posho (maize flour)	and fish. 

To help expand her business, Hadiya has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities such as rice and maize flour for the store and will help Hadiya to generate greater profits and help the borrower increase sales from the stock, hence improving living standards. Hadiya hopes that in the future she will be able to own her own supermarket. 

Hadiya is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hadiya who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more commodities such as rice and maize flour for the store

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastulla is 49 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is widowed and has two children.  For the past 4 years, Mastulla has been working hard to manage her salon, which works on women and men's hair with a video library that rents out video tapes and cds. 

To help expand her business into a big unisex salon, Mastulla has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a dryer,a steamer and video tapes for renting out to her customers and will help Mastulla to generate greater profits and increase her daily sales.  Mastulla hopes that in the future she will be able to own a unisex salon. 

Mastulla is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mastulla who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase a dryer and a steamer for her salon.

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
"Christine's group" is comprised of 2 hard working women. Christine is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono, in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, and 1 of them is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Christine has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fast foods. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 400000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cassava, Irish potatoes and cooking oil that will be fried for resale, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and expand the business. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a big hotel. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more cassava, Irish potatoes, and cooking oil that will be fried for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel Ratisbonne

texts.fr:
Emmanuel Ratisbonne est un homme âgé de 40 ans, fiancé et père de deux enfants, tous allant déjà à l'école. comme activité, il dispose d'un comptoir dans un quartier de la ville sur lequel il vend des bonbons, biscuits, cigarettes depuis 01 an. il y offre également des services d'appel téléphonique en plus de la vente des crédits de communication. le suivi de son activité est assuré grâce aux notions de gestion et de comptabilité qu'il a acquises à l'école. il voudrait avec ce crédit non seulement acheter les biscuits, des bonbons, du pétrole et de l'huile pour renforcer son stock de marchandise, mais aussi acheter des crédits de communication pour élever son volume de transaction.
il a pour ambition d'économiser non seulement pour se marier, mais aussi il voudrait ouvrir une boutique.
texts.en: Emmanuel Ratisbonne is a 40 year old man, engaged to be married, and father of two children, both of whom attend school. He has a stand in a neighborhood of the city from which he has been selling candy, cookies, crackers and cigarettes for the past year. He also offers his customers long-distance phone call services and sells communication credits. He manages his business well thanks to the accounting and business skills he acquired in school. He is asking for a loan in order to purchase more merchandise to sell (candy, cookies, motor oil and cooking oil) but also to purchase additional communication credits so he can increase his volume of sales. He hopes to save his profits not only to spend on the wedding, but also to open a real store.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Ababacar

texts.fr:
Marié et père de 4 enfants monsieur Ababacar habite dans une des localités villageoises du Sénégal. Il évolue depuis plus de six ans dans le secteur des services. Il détient un véhicule de transport en commun qui lui procure des revenus réguliers grâce auxquels il parvient a entretenir sa famille  et  son véhicule. Il est membre du guichet de l’UIMCEC de sa zone d’habitation. Il sollicite un crédit de 400 000  frs prévu pour l’entretien de son véhicule. Ce financement pourra l’aider a renforcer les revenus qu’il gagne de son activité et de continuer a faire face a ses responsabilités de chef de famille.  Son souhait dans le futur est de disposer d’un parc automobile de 3 a 4 taxis.
-
texts.en: A married man and the father of four children, Ababacar lives in a small village in Senegal. For the past six years his commercial activity has been increasing. He owns a motorized vehicle that serves as a method of shared transportation for passengers, providing him with regular income that he spends on taking care of his family's needs in addition to the maintenace of this vehicle. He is a member of the UIMCEC branch near his home. He is asking for a loan of 400,000 FCFA (approximately 800 USD) that he will spend on the maintenance of his vehicle. This loan will help him increase his revenues and allow him to continue to cover the costs of his family, a responsiblity which he bears, as head of the household. He hopes to someday own a taxi company that would have 3 or 4 vehicles.

loans.use: look after the maintenance of his vehicle.

loans.name: Marie Michelle

texts.fr:
Marie Michelle est une jeune Camerounaise âgée de 26 ans, mariée et mère de 03 enfants dont l'âge varie entre 02 et 06 ans et parmi lesquels 02 vont à l'école. elle mène une activité de confection des vêtement à domicile depuis 02 ans déjà. elle coud sur commande et ensuite les livres en gros auprès des détaillants. elle travaille seule et ne dispose que d'une seule machine. elle voudrait avec ce crédit acheter une surfileuse, des tissus et le petit matériel de couture pour confectionner des vêtements et coussins destinés à l'exposition-vente au lieu d'attendre uniquement les commandes.
elle a pour ambition d'ouvrir un atelier de couture
texts.en: Marie Michelle is a young 26 year old Camerounian woman, married and the mother of three children aged between 2 and 6 years old, two of whom attend school. For the past two years, she has been making and selling clothes from her home. She sews based on orders and then delivers bulk quantities to wholesale retaliers. She works on her own and owns only one machine. She is asking for a loan in order to purchase an additional sewing machine, more cloth, and other sewing materials so she can make clothes and pillows to be sold at a later date, rather than always relying on customer orders. She hopes to one day open a sewing workshop.

loans.use: purchase a sewing machine and more cloth

loans.name: Kimutai

texts.en:
Kimutai is a 23-year-old farmer from Litein county in Kenya, where he lives with his wife and one young child. He has been in farming for the past four years, producing milk, tea and vegetables, which he sells at the local market. He is also employed in another job as an additional source of income.

Kimutai is requesting a 60,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase materials for constructing a dairy unit. This will help him to manage his dairy cows in a better way and thus increase milk production. The extra income will help him boost his living standards and pay for her child's schooling. He aspires to buy another cow that produces more milk in the next five years.

A readily available market and strong competition are his major challenges in farming. Kimutai is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the support it offers its clients.

loans.use: To purchase materials for constructing a dairy unit

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta is a 64-year-old resident of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. Julieta supported her two children's needs from the little amount of 5,000 PHP she earns monthly from her gardening business for 20 years. However in 2010 she became a member of GDMPC, and she applied for a loan at GDMPC micro finance of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Julieta wants to expand her business one day.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita is 33 years old. She is married and she has eight children; three of them are in school. She has a kiosk in front of her house. To improve her kiosk, she is requesting a loan to buy more stock to keep in her kiosk. She has been doing business for the past three years. She lives in her simple house with her family. She hopes to build a good house and make her business bigger in the future.

loans.use: to buy drinks, biscuits, noodles and a refrigerator to keep drinks cold.

loans.name: Muhamadi

texts.en:
Muhamadi is aged 30 with four children, living in Masindi, Uganda. He bakes local pizza known as "chapati" and has been in business ever since he dropped out school due to lack of school fees. He is a hardworking man who is determined to change his life and that of his children by educating them to attain degrees as minimum qualification. His business is located on a busy street where the people in town can easily access him. 

Muhamadi's hardships are high cost of ingredients and competition while his business dream is to own a modern bakery. Muhamadi is requesting a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Habibullo

texts.ru:
Хабибулло проживает в районе Рудаки. Ему 41 год. Он разведен. У него двое детей. Хабибулло занимается торговлей. В этой области он десять лет. На сегодняшний день Хабибулло открыл собственный продуктовый магазин и он намерен расширить свою деятельность (развивать свой бизнес). 
Хабибулло берет кредит для покупки необходимых продуктов и подарков, чтобы увеличить оборот и ассортимент товара под новый год.
texts.en: Habibullo lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. He is 41 years old, divorced, and has two children. Habibullo has been engaged in retail activity for the past ten years. Presently, he operates his own grocery store, and has plans to develop and expand his business. He is taking this loan to purchase necessary food products and gifts in order to increase his sales volume and expand the assortment of his merchandise prior to New Year.

loans.use: to buy food products and gifts in order to increase his sales volume and expand the range of his merchandise in advance of New Year

loans.name: Altansukh

texts.en:
Altansukh is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in their house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. 

Altansukh is a Buddhist monk, and since 1991, he has been helping people who are in need of support in spiritual or psychological matters. His wife helps him and manages his back issues. His daughter studies at a university, and the other two attend a secondary school. 

Altansukh has principles, and helping people is his main goal. He never charges anyone; that is strictly established. His family lives on endowment that people give. 

Altansukh is asking a 2,000,000 MNT loan to pay for his daughter’s tuition.

loans.use: to pay for his daughter’s tuition.

loans.name: Estephanie Jane

texts.en:
Estephanie Jane of Sinian, Baliangao helps support her family through her charcoal-making business. She’s 22 years old and married with one child and she tries her best to earn on her own. For two years, she has managed this business and earns about 3,500 PHP per month. Now, she’s needs to pay for the labor cost in charcoal making. She joined recently and thanks GDMPC micro finance for the loan of 7,000 PHP they provided to her. 

Estephanie Jane desires to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to pay for the labor cost in charcoal making

loans.name: Tamila

texts.en:
Tamila is 29 years old. She lives with her husband in Kutaisi District, West Georgia. Tamila requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the small income earned by Tamila’s husband, working as cook locally. That makes in total 250 Laris per month. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Tamila requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Tamila will sell clothing and bed-clothes. She plans to purchase clothing and bed-clothes from wholesalers and resell the goods locally. That will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to sell clothing and bed-clothes

loans.name: Inga

texts.en:
Inga is 46 years old and lives with her daughter and son-in-law in the Kutaisi district of West Georgia. She has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times in order to start up a family business, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected every time because of the family's low income and poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is Inga's work as a local cook. She makes a total of 250 laris per month, which is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo's assessment, the family belongs to the "subsistence poor" category. 

Inga has requested a loan from Credo for a family business start-up. Her loan request was approved under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides credit for business start-ups, offering favorable loan conditions to poor rural people who do not have access to credit because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers”. Using the loan, Inga will set up a new business trading in clothing and bed-clothes. She plans to purchase clothing from wholesalers and resell it locally. This new business initiative will significantly improve the income and living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to begin a new business in clothing sales

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en: Gregoria, 53, resident of Dinas, Sinacaban. Gregoria supports her 4 children with the small amount of 4,000 PHP.  She makes this amount monthly from her gardening business of 5 years. This year she joined GDMPC and she has applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Gregoria wants to expand her business one day.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is from Iraq. He is a youthful client only 19 years old. He is single and lives with 4 family members. He and his father are the only providers for the family.

Ahmad owns a store that rents kitchenware. He established his business in 2009 and now he has one employee. He has built good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.
He is requesting a sum of $2,400 to rent a warehouse. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide better life conditions for his family.

loans.use: to rent a warehouse

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en: Rodel is married with 2 children. Rodel is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. Rodel manages a gardening business to earn a living. He has been doing this for 3 years. Every month he earn 4,500 php from this work. He has requested a loan of 10,000 php to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizer. Rodel joined GDMPC this year. Rodel hopes to double his income from the business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seedlings, and fertilizer

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells ground pepper, spices, and shrimp at Elmina market which she has done for some years now. She is married with 4 children.  She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their children’s school fees.  Elizabeth will use her loan to purchase ground pepper, spices, and  shrimp. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: purchase ground pepper, spices, and  shrimp

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joeniel

texts.en: Joeniel is 24 years old and is a married entrepreneur of San Roque, Panaon. He has 2 children and earns a living from his transport service business. He began this business almost 3 years ago and he earns 4,000 PHP a month. To improve his business, he has asked to borrow 8,000 PHP from GDMPC Micro Credit which he joined in 2011.  The loan is to obtain accessories and tires. He’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business.

loans.use: to obtain accessories and tires

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 28 years old and married. She sells secondhand clothes. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy more clothes to sell. She has been operating this business for the past year.

She earns a good income. She lives in the city next to a garden, and many people come to buy things from her kiosk.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace sells groundnut charcoal at the Elmina market, which she has done for some years now. She is married with three children. She uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their home.  

Grace will use her loan to purchase bags of groundnuts to make charcoal for sale. With the new profits she earns, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of groundnuts to make charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina sells gari (tapioca), rice, sugar, canned tomatoes and canned fish in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. She has gone to school through junior high school. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a mason.  

Regina has been selling canned fish, canned tomatoes, gari (tapioca), rice and sugar for three years. She is responsible for caring for her young children and saving money to pay for their eventual schooling. Her loan will be used to buy boxes of canned fish and tomatoes, bags of rice, sugar and gari. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy boxes of canned fish and tomatoes, bags of rice, sugar and gari (tapioca).

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, commercial maize and sorghum seed.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy various goods such as beans, potatoes, rice, sorghum, etc. for resale in his general store.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a dried fish business in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 15 years.  She earns additional income from a general store. 

Susan is requesting a loan from NWTF for 28,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional fish for her making dried fish.  She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. In the future, she hopes to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish for making dried fish.

loans.name: Jabbar

texts.en:
Jabbar is 41 years old, married, and has five children, one of whom is employed.  He is from Iraq. Jabbar owns a store selling tools and supplies, which he has been doing since 2009. He has one employee. He has good experience in the field and is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

Jabbar is requesting a loan for $3,000, which he will use to make new shelves and a new roof for his store. He hope to expand his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to make new shelves and a new roof for his store.

loans.name: Hafisa

texts.en:
Hafisa is a 43 year old, married, and has four children.  She lives in Masindi, Uganda.  Hafisa bakes bread, which she has been doing for twelve years. With the proceeds, she has been able to buy land and pay school fees for her children.

Hafisa is requesting a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat and cooking oil. She has a challenge of the high cost of raw materials. She hopes to educate her children up to the university level and open another outlet.

loans.use: to buy wheat and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, commercial maize, and sorghum seed.

loans.name: Margalita

texts.en:
Margalita is from the Chokhatauri district. She is 34 years old, married and lives with her family: her husband and parents-in-law. Her husband works as a police officer and her mother-in-law is a doctor locally. Both of family members get monthly salaries. Besides, Margalita’s father-in-law is provided with a retirement pension. 

Margalita has requested loan from local financial institutions several times for a business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because of lack of experience in new business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.

Her loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the requested loan, Margalita will start up a dental clinic locally. She will purchase dental equipment and operative supplies to satisfy the professional needs of the dentists that will be working at her clinic. Margalita hopes her business will be profitable because of the price range and well qualified dentists. This will increase her income and the family members will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs, in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and supplies for starting a dental clinic.

loans.name: Mary Cris

texts.en:
Mary Cris is 22 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 11,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, spices, etc.

Mary Cris has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from selling coconut shells.

Mary Cris aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, spices, etc.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Desde que recibió su credikiva, Luz ha mejoado en su negocio y en su familia, pues pudo ofrecer diseños diversificados,mejores acabados y una terraza mucho mas amplia donde compartir con su familia.En la actualidad va a aplicar a un nuevo creidkiva, con el cual comprará matrias primas e inumos en mayor volumen pues  está preparandose para la época de final de año, temporada en la cual su clientela aumenta, pues todos quieren verse elegantes y bien vestidos con sus costuras. Esto es lo que hace que su credikiva sea exitoso. Su mensaje a Kiva es el siguiente: " agradecimiento total a los finaciadores porque poco a poco he mejorado, tanto en mi negocio, como mi casa. "
texts.en:
Since she received her Kiva loan, Luz has improved in her work and in her family life.  She has been able to offer a diverse set of designs, better finishing touches to her home, and a much larger and more open patio where she can share time with her family. 

At present, she is applying for a new Kiva loan that she will use to buy raw materials and sewing supplies in large volume.  She is preparing for the New Year season, a time when her number of customers grows; everyone wants to see themselves looking elegant and well-dressed in their clothing.

This is what she will do with her loan if her application is successful.  Her message to Kiva is the following: "gratitude to all of the financial backers because little by little, I have improved, as much in my business as in my home."

loans.use: to buy fabrics and supplies for making clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Jane has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice that will be sold. This will help Jane to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business. 

Jane is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice that will be sold.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 47 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in Khelvachauri District, West Georgia. Her husband works as an artisan locally and gets a monthly income. Her economic activity is a newly started business. In particular, a grocery store. 

Eva requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for further developing her business, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of lack of experience in her business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.
  
Her loan request was approved within the frames of new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Eva will cover the costs of purchasing her stock of basic groceries for starting a grocery store. She plans to work hard and increase the turnover in her business gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. 

With this loan, her family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event they need it.

loans.use: to purchase stock of basic groceries for starting a grocery store.

loans.name: Kosay

texts.en:
Kosay is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and has one child. Kosay is the only provider of the family.

Kosay owns a small restaurant/café. He established his business in 2003 and now he has two employees. He has built a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a loan of $2,000 to paint his restaurant/café and to install a new floor. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

loans.use: to paint his restaurant/café and to install a new floor.

loans.name: Jamiila

texts.en:
Jamiila is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Jamiila has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells raw food. 

To help expand her business, Jamiila has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food such as matooke (steamed green bananas) and sweet potatoes for resale. It will help Jamiila to generate greater profits and take care of herself and buy basic needs for the family. Jamiila hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business than what she has now. 

Jamiila is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more food such as matooke and sweet potatoes for sale in her food stall.

loans.name: Allen's Group

texts.en:
Allen's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Allen is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, Allen has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Allen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale, and will help Allen to generate greater profits, which will be used to buy food at home. Allen hopes that in the future she will be able to earn more, which will help take care of her family. 

Allen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Nadia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Nadia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap. This will help Nadia to generate greater profits and expand her business into a bigger shop and to buy more items for the shop, which will increase her capital. Nadia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Nadia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for her store.

loans.name: Ismaeil

texts.en:
Ismaeil is from Iraq. He is 46 years old, married and has four children. Ismaeil is the only provider of the family. He owns a small grocery store selling soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents and snacks. He established his business in 2006. He is well known in the surrounding area and has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting an $1,800 loan to install a new floor in his mini-market and to increase his inventory. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to install a new floor in his mini-market and to increase his inventory.

loans.name: Hadijja

texts.en:
Hadijja is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past year, Hadijja has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells fruits. 

To help expand her business, Hadijja has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits like tomatoes and will help Hadijja to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Hadijja hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger food stall. 

Hadijja is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fruits like tomatoes for resale

loans.name: Aby
